Award.AwardTitle: Superconductor-Insulator Transitions in Disordered Ultrathin Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Abstract

This project will pursue experiments that probe superconductor?insulator (SI) transitions in simple two-dimensional metallic systems. These transitions are believed to be continuous quantum phase transitions (QPTs). The QPT is an important paradigm in contemporary condensed matter physics. A QPT, in contrast with a thermally driven phase transition, occurs at zero temperature with the ground state being changed in response to the variation of an external parameter. The fluctuations associated with QPTs are quantum mechanical rather than classical. Measurements at nonzero temperature in the critical regime can reveal these quantum fluctuations and can be used to characterize them. Other systems exhibiting QPTs include two-dimensional electron gases, compounds with strongly correlated electrons, and certain cold atom systems. The experiments that will be pursued will answer open questions regarding the nature of physical models governing SI transitions tuned with external parameters such as disorder, dissipation, charge density, and magnetic field, the nature of the insulating state, the influence of material properties, and the nature of the critical region, where new physics often emerges. The investigations will include measurements of transport and magneto-transport, electrical noise, the Nernst effect, and the electronic compressibility at the transition. The work requires advanced tools of experimental science including nanofabrication and ultra-low temperature physics. This project will support the education of PhD students and undergraduates in a manner that is excellent training for scientific careers from academia to high technology industries.

Nontechnical Abstract

Quantum mechanics is the theory describing the sub-microscopic world. Of contemporary interest is the nature of its role in the macroscopic world. Thermodynamic phase transitions are transitions between disordered and ordered phases. Their microscopic mechanisms are always quantum mechanical. In such transitions the macroscopic behavior, in particular the spatial and temporal fluctuations of the degree of order found near the transition, is classical. Quantum phase transitions are transitions between disordered and ordered phases, occurring at absolute zero. Instead of temperature, they are controlled by changes in external parameters such as magnetic field, pressure or charge density. In contrast with thermodynamic transitions, their fluctuations are quantum mechanical, and they persist at nonzero temperatures thus allowing their study. This project is focused on the investigation of the simplest quantum phase transitions, superconductor-insulator transitions in two-dimensions. The experiments that will be pursued will answer open questions regarding the macroscopic quantum fluctuations associated with these transitions and explore new physics that emerges near the transitions. The work has implications for other areas of research as quantum phase transitions occur in two-dimensional electron gases, compounds with strongly correlated electrons, and certain cold atom systems. The proposed experiments require advanced tools of experimental science including nanofabrication and ultra-low temperature physics. This project will support the education of PhD students and undergraduates in a manner that is excellent training for scientific careers from academia to high technology industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This basic research project has been focused on the investigation of several of the simplest quantum phase transitions, the superconductor-insulator transitions of two-dimensional systems. By two-dimensional we refer to films of metals or compounds that are thinner than a characteristic length scale for superconductivity called the coherence length. Quantum phase transitions are different from conventional thermodynamic phase transitions. The latter are transitions between a high temperature disordered phase and a low temperature ordered phase. The onsets of superconductivity and ferromagnetism are examples.  Thermodynamic transitions occur at material and phenomenon dependent characteristic temperatures. Their microscopic mechanisms are described by quantum mechanics.  However their macroscopic behavior, in particular the spatial and temporal fluctuations of the degree of order found near the transition, are classical. These fluctuations are responsible for the macroscopic thermodynamic properties found near the onset temperature.  

 Quantum mechanics is the theory describing the atomic-scale regime.  Of contemporary interest is the nature of its impact in the macroscopic regime.  Quantum phase transitions are transitions that occur at absolute zero between disordered and ordered phases. Instead of being controlled by temperature, these transitions are controlled by changes in external parameters of the system such as magnetic field, pressure, chemical composition, or charge density.  In contrast with thermodynamic transitions, the fluctuations associated with these transitions are quantum mechanical, and persist at nonzero temperature. The measurable signatures of these fluctuations allow for the characterization of transitions that occur at the unattainable absolute zero of temperature.   Frequently novel physical effects emerge in the vicinity of quantum phase transitions.  Quantum phase transitions are an important paradigm in contemporary condensed matter science and understanding their nature is an important challenge. Superconductor-insulator transitions in two dimensions are among the simplest quantum phase transitions, and they are of particular importance because of their close connection to the Heisenberg Uncertainty Principle of quantum mechanics.

  The experiments pursued have been directed at open questions regarding superconductor-insulator transitions and were designed to explore new physics associated with them. The study of superconductor-insulator transitions has required advanced tools of experimental science such as nanofabrication, controlled thin film growth, and ultra-low temperature cryogenic measurement. This project has supported the education of both Ph.D. and undergraduate students in a manner that is excellent training for scientific careers from academia to high technology industry.  The work has implications for other areas of research, as quantum phase transitions occur in two-dimensional electron gases, in strongly correlated electron systems, and in certain cold atom systems. 

 There have been two areas of research that have defined the project.  The first involves the study of the nature of the giant peak in the resistance found when a sufficiently high magnetic field drives a nominally homogeneous amorphous superconducting film into an insulating state. We have found that mesoscale disorder in the form of thickness or chemical variations is necessary in order for a system to exhibit such a peak. This implies that the insulating regime in a magnetic field is not a new state of matter as has been previously claimed, and may be explained using conventional ideas. Nevertheless, we discovered a phase transition between two different insulating regimes controlled by magnetic field, which is yet to be explained
